title: Patient Name
instruction: Only return the patients name and not the doctors name or anyone else's name

title: Chief Complaint
instruction: Please provide only the patient's chief complaint without any additional details or context. Avoid direct speech.

title: History of Present Illness
content: Milo reports pain in his middle finger. He has an ingrown nail that is approximately 70% ingrown, with good nail growth from the proximal 30%. He denies avoiding activities and is able to fully flex and extend the finger with no limitation. No erythema or signs of infection noted. He remains active and engages in normal play and daily tasks.
instruction: Provide a detailed summary of the patient's current illness based on their report. Include a thorough description of symptoms, noting their onset, duration, and severity or intensity. Discuss any changes or developments in symptoms since their onset and identify factors that may exacerbate or relate to these symptoms, such as specific activities, foods, or medications. Document any prior treatments or remedies the patient has attempted, noting their efficacy. Describe how these symptoms impact the patient's daily activities, overall well-being, and quality of life. Capture information about any individuals mentioned by the patient, specifying their relationship and any pertinent interactions or conversations related to the illness. Please recheck the sentence and correct any grammatical errors in the following medical-related template. Ensure clarity, professionalism, and proper medical terminology while maintaining a concise and structured format. End the sentence with period. Avoid direct speech and avoid talking in first person.

title: Past Medical History
instruction: Should include a comprehensive overview of the patient's previous medical conditions, surgeries, and significant health events.Any chronic or significant medical conditions the patient has been diagnosed with in the past, such as diabetes, hypertension, asthma, heart disease, etc.Any previous surgeries the patient has undergone in the past, including the type of surgery, date, and outcomes. Any previous hospital admissions, not related to the present illness, including the reason for admission, dates, and outcomes. Do not include current visits doctors assessment and plan in this section. This can include the assessments and plans of the previous doctors visits.

title: Current Medications
instruction: Document the patient's current medications in the following format: Begin with the full generic name of each medication, followed by the brand name in parentheses if applicable (e.g., "Aspirin (Bayer)"). Specify the dosage strength (e.g., "81 mg") and indicate the frequency of administration (e.g., "Once daily"). Describe the route of administration, such as oral, topical, or by injection (e.g., "Oral Aspirin"). Lastly, for ongoing medications, note the duration for which the patient has been taking each medication (e.g., "on Aspirin for 3 weeks"). If no current medications are reported, document "No current medications found."

title: Family History
instruction: Extract the family history details shared by the patient. Focus on documenting any relevant medical conditions, hereditary diseases, mental health issues, or notable health events in the patient's immediate and extended family. Specify the relation of the family members to the patient and include the age at diagnosis or occurrence of any significant health issues if mentioned. If no relevant family history is provided, default to "No family history found.

default: Eyes: No visual loss, blurred vision, double vision.  Ears, Nose, Throat:  No hearing loss, sneezing, congestion, runny nose or sore throat.

title: Lab Results
instruction: Document the patient's past lab results based on tests previously conducted, as discussed in the conversation. Include the date of each test, the type of test performed (such as blood tests, urine tests, imaging studies like X-rays or MRIs, or other diagnostic procedures), and the specific results reported by the patient. Ensure accuracy and clarity in reporting, focusing solely on tests already completed by the patient. Do not include lab tests prescribed by the doctor during the current visit.

title: Assessment and Plan
content: Diagnosis: Ingrown nail of the middle finger with associated pain. No signs of infection or deformity. Plan: Advance activities tolerated, advance range of motion tolerated. Continue to monitor pain and nail growth. No new medications prescribed. Educated patient on gentle nail care and avoiding tight footwear.
instruction: Assessment:Provide a detailed note of the patient's current health status based on the information gathered during the visit. This should include:Diagnosis or Differential Diagnosis: List the primary diagnosis or possible diagnoses based on the assessment. Include a differential diagnosis if there is uncertainty or multiple potential causes.Pertinent Positive and Negative Findings: Highlight key findings from the patient's history, physical examination, and diagnostic tests that support the diagnosis or influence the treatment plan.Severity or Progression: Describe the severity of the condition, if applicable, and any changes observed since the last visit.Comorbidities: Note any other existing medical conditions that may impact the patient's current health status or treatment plan.Plan:Detail the healthcare provider's plan of action to manage the patient's condition. This should include:Treatment Plan: Specify the interventions or treatments recommended for the patient, such as medications, procedures, therapies, lifestyle modifications, or referrals to specialists.Medication Management: Detail any new medications prescribed, changes to existing medications, or discontinuation of medications. Include dosage, frequency, route of administration, and duration of treatment.Patient Education: Provide information to the patient regarding their condition, the treatment plan, potential side effects of medications, and instructions for self-care or symptom management.Referrals: If necessary, refer the patient to other healthcare providers or specialists for further evaluation or management of specific aspects of their care.Counseling or Support Services: Recommend any counseling services, support groups, or resources that may benefit the patient in coping with their condition or treatment. and don't include any related to follow up in the plan

title: Follow Up
content: Return to clinic in six to eight weeks for follow-up.
instruction: Outline the schedule for follow-up appointments based on the information gathered during the visit. Include the following details if present:Next Appointment: Schedule the next appointment for [date/time].Review and Adjustments: Plan for reviewing the patient's progress and making necessary adjustments to the treatment plan during the follow-up appointment.
